templates.name: What is your Sharp for Life program?
templates.content: Our Sharp for Life program is a free sharpening service for Lamson knives. Since our knives are built to last a lifetime, we're happy to help keep them sharp for as long as you have them. For just the cost of shipping, our professionals will put a fresh edge on your knives and have them sharp as new again. Follow the link for additional instructions: https://lamsonproducts.com/care-and-support/#sharp-for-life

templates.name: What is G-10 handle material?
templates.content:
Developed by Westinghouse, G-10 has proved its toughness and durability in both electrical and mechanical device applications. It's constructed from woven glass and epoxy resin, formed under high heat and pressure. The resulting material is incredibly strong, resistant to temperature, impervious to moisture and has a beautiful deep shine when polished.

Your G-10 handle requires exceptionally low maintenance. It will not rust or oxidize, nor will it become brittle or soften over time. A light rub with mineral oil will bring out the natural brilliance and sheen. Among its other uses, G-10 is an ideal material for knife handles, as it is light, doesn't expand or contract due to normal temperature and moisture exposure, and is extremely rugged.

templates.name: What is Pom handle material?
templates.content: POM (Polyoxymethylene) also known as Acetal or Polyacetal, is an engineering thermoplastic used in precision parts requiring high stiffness, high strength, and excellent wear resistance. It also has almost no moisture retention, making it an ideal material for Knife and Tool handles.

templates.name: What is a Sierra Striated Wood Handle?
templates.content: Striated wood is also known as Pakkawood. It's a very popular choice for kitchen knife handles. It's a wood and resin layered composite that is carefully manufactured to increase the grip capability and durability of the handle. Striated/Pakkawood has good resistance to extreme heat and moisture exposure, however it's not dishwasher safe. When polished, the handle has a deep rich texture showing the various layers of composite.

templates.name: What are Nickel Silver rivets?
templates.content: Nickel Silver is a copper alloy with nickel and zinc. The usual formulation is 60% copper, 20% nickel, and 20% zinc. Nickel silver is named due to its silvery appearance, but it contains no actual silver. Nickel Silver is non-magnetic.

templates.name: Do you ship internationally?
templates.content: Yes, we do! We currently ship to over 200 countries worldwide.

templates.name: What do I do if I see spots on my knife blade?
templates.content:
We use the best quality Hi-Carbon stainless steel in our knives to ensure the best hardness, best edge retention, and ease of sharpening. All steel alloys, especially those with Hi-Carbon are prone to surface discoloring or even rust if knives are not cared for correctly. To ensure your knives stay stain-free, always remember to hand-wash in warm soapy water after each use and then immediately dry thorougly with a soft cloth.

If spots appear, these are generally just surface "patina" discolorations that can be easily removed. We recommed using Bar Keepers Friend. It's a great product to keep any steel in fine shape and you can check it out here: https://lamsonproducts.com/collections/sharpening-honing-protection/products/bar-keepers-friend-cleaner-26-oz

templates.name: What is Walnut handle material?
templates.content: Walnut is a hard, dense, tight-grained wood with a distinctive dark color. It is commonly used for furniture, paneling, knobs, and handles. On our Forged Walnut and Vintage Walnut tools, we infuse the walnut with resin, sealing it from moisture. For our other walnut-handled tools, we leave their handles in their natural state, with a light application of mineral oil.

templates.name: How do I hone a knife?
templates.content: Hold your sharpening steel vertically on a non-slip base. Hold the knife at a 20-degree angle to the steel's shaft, then draw the knife in one smooth motion from the heel of the blade to the tip. Repeat five to six times on each side. Be sure to use the same number of strokes for each side. You can also check out our YouTube video for more information here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dY2W8wLLl5s&ab_channel=LamsonProducts
